awd_abstract_narration:
The Summer Geometry Initiative (SGI) is an intensive summer program aimed at helping student researchers in the field of geometry processing.  Geometry processing addresses algorithms, software, and theory relevant to computing over geometric data; the fields brings together mathematics, computer science, and engineering expertise needed to work with 3D models in a range of applications.  The summer program provides opportunities for SGI Fellows to engage deeply with current research and work with experienced mentors.  This year, the summer program leadership is also working closely with the Symposium on Geometry Processing, a leading conference in the area.  This will provide additional opportunities for students to engage with the research community, including interacting with alumni who have participated in past iterations of the workshop.

This grant will support stipends, travel, and registration support for about 13 students who otherwise have limited funding and so might not be able to participate in the summer institute or the conference.  Criteria for selection include financial need and growing the size and breadth of the geometry processing community, with a particular focus on providing opportunities for students who would not otherwise be likely to get involved in the field.  Prior sessions of the summer program have had demonstrated impact on alumni's graduate work and careers, while elements of the summer program will also be made more widely available through a talk series and tutorials with accompanying materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Support was used to continue the Summer Geometry Initiative (SGI) in 2024, a summer program introducing undergraduates and early master's students to applied geometry research.

Funding also supported a new grant for SGI alumni to attend the Symposium on Geometry Processing (SGP) in person, supporting our goal of making geometry processing accessible to newcomers.

SGI 2024 took place during six weeks in summer 2024.  The program supported 33 Fellows, who participated full-time; ~20 more participated in the initial week.  The first week featured a set of tutorials and interactive exercises to introduce participants to theoretical concepts and software tools in geometry processing, with no assumption on past experience (beyond linear algebra, calculus, and programming).  The remaining five weeks were dedicated to research experiences, mostly 1-2 week collaborations led by top faculty and scientists.

SGI 2024 was overwhelmingly successful, exceeding expectations for the technical and broader impact-oriented aims of the program.  Highlights include:

  • 81.8% of SGI Fellows (among survey respondents) self-identified as members of an underrepresented group in computing or mathematical sciences, and numerous countries were represented among the fellows.
  • After the program, many SGI Fellows reported that they were likely to pursue graduate education (MS, PhD) in geometry processing and related fields.  Many 2024 Fellows reported submitting applications to top programs.  Several SGI faculty mentors reported they were likely to recruit SGI Fellows.
  • Similarly to the previous offerings, SGI 2024 was held completely online.  The program pioneers techniques in online research-based education.
  • MIT EECS uses SGI as a model for efforts promoting diversity among graduate program applicants, included in MIT EECS's strategic plan.
  • Research projects launched during SGI continued beyond the end of the program, and we are seeing papers submitted to conferences/journals.

Readers are invited to visit the SGI 2024 blog for write-ups by SGI Fellows describing their projects: http://summergeometry.org/sgi2024

Since 2024 was the first time that SGP was held in the USA, part of this grant was used to give a set of travel grants to students to attend in person.  In total, we awarded four travel grants that covered the entire cost to fly to SGP and attend the entire conference (including tutorials); we also awarded two conference registrations to local students who did not need travel.  All awardees attended the entire conference and networking events, where they interacted with potential PhD advisors/collaborators; each submitted a report at the end of the program.

Data collection among the participants (Fellows and mentors) reflected many of the positive points above.  Example student feedback includes:

  • "I never though[t] that theory of geometry can be applied in such a rich way and that the discrete analogs also shed light back into old math problems. Happy to see a lot of people. This is really a community... SGI really opens many new possibilities for me."
  • "The tutorial week as an absolutely incredible opportunity to level the playing field for the SGI fellows and introduce us to the world of geometry processing if we did not yet have that background. I was very grateful to hear speakers talk before the start of the program and it truly helped with my transition into a successful SGI research period."
  • "I love this model. It provides the opportunity for someone to build the foundations of becoming a polymath in such a short period. I feel like I have learned so so much in computer vision, math and software engineering. The small sprints keep the enthusiasm alive throughout the whole program. The versatility in the program is unique, if one is not satisfied with the theme of their project, the next week they can hop on a different one, rather than being stuck, as one would be in any other internship. And most importantly, having worked with so many people, of different cultures, backgrounds and fields, on so many different research questions, broadened my mind more than I could have ever anticipated; I am not the same researcher or even person as before SGI. I don't believe I could have gotten this opportunity via any other program."
  • "Literally, reading the project descriptions before we started made my heart beat fast (little excessive I know but I was waiting for such a research experience for a long time); I was so excited to be a part of many of them! And the best part? They didn't let me down. Sadly, I couldn't choose them all."
  • "SGI has significantly enhanced my ability to read and understand research papers, even those in entirely new fields...During SGI, I discovered a method that works best for me to grasp the main ideas, methodologies, and approaches to reproducing the core concepts presented in papers."

Planning for SGI 2025 is underway. The latest version has received overwhelming interest among students who wish to participate as well as faculty who wish to be mentors.
